Topic.Title: AMZN is Just as Much "Bricks and Mortar" than WMT and Best Buy

Message.Msg: Yes, yet sales continue to grow at a fast clip. Amazon is virtually the only place where you can buy anything hassle free. I find myself going there for price checks and for items I think may not be in stock at stores or may be hard to find at stores. For example, I needed a door lock replacement part the other day. I could have spent an hour looking at home depot with no guarantee they would even have it. Plus there is huge value to the reviews you just don't get at stores. Add in the sales tax savings, and those reasons are why amazon is growing. I can imagine market cap going to $200m before a crash, so I'm shorting carefully. Its harder to short a stock when you find yourself giving them business, but its all about valuation in the long run.

Topic.Title: never see a bond issuance that was so overlooked/ or just celebrated as the one AMZN has in December

That's the world you get with Fed interest rate artificial market suppression I guess. There will be another period ahead of being exposed at being asleep at the wheel with all these corporate bonds issuance that should have carried much more risk to their ratings.

Message.Title: International shipping up 50%
Message.Msg: It's amazing how clueless the stock analysts are. I see no articles about the huge USPS price hike. Non U.S. buyers are looking at a 50% rate hike on packages under 4 pounds. Just an outrageous move by the post office which is sure to kill millions of sales to non-U.S. buyers. The cd that came with $5 shipping is now $10 shipping. And because Amazon foolishly will not allow sellers to charge more for shipping; millions of sellers are now not offering overseas or they'd lose money on those sales. Suddenly the international buyers are cut out of buying and yet I see no articles onthis anywhere. This is why Amazon has tanked for 2 days. Does anyone have a clue what's actually going on???

Topic.Title: I've been a long time bear on Amazon and never had much success shorting it

Message.Msg: on the feb 1's: going long 100 of the 240 contracts would be a cost of $312,000 less the revenue from selling 100 of the 280 contracts which is $75,000. So, since your maximum loss on the position would be $312,000 - $75000 = $237,000 and your max gain is capped you can purchase $237,000 / 3375 (price of 240 contract) which = 70 contracts. this is the same risk, but if the stock passes 280 you dont cap your gains.

Topic.Title: Question for anyone: If they miss analyst expectations, aren't they

Message.Msg: No - they have nothing to do with analyst expectations (at least legally) ... they guided to a much lower revenue number ($20.25B - $22.75B), and a huge range on earnings (-$1.07 to +0.67). As long as they come within that they are fine from a shareholder suit perspective. Analysts pumped the stock up over the past quarter (to a tune of 30% from 218-284) by taking the high end of that range ($22.3B in revs and $0.29 in EPS). Whisper is now at $0.33 .... So you can only be confident that they will not below $20.25B of revenue and less than ($1.07) of negative earnings.

Message.Title: At this price - AMZN is a complete joke by Wall street
Message.Msg: Quite simply, a company that has been around over 10 years(not a small, new growth company) and a market cap of $125 billion - CANNOT grow into a multiple of 3,500. AMZN could be involved in EVERY retail transaction on the planet, and at their margin the company cannot earn enough to bring the multiple to a value level. Lomg term, the P/E of AMZN should be around 20, that would mean earnings of $13.50 given its price of $270 today. Currently, .07 cents earnings growing to $13.50 - impossible. The next recession takes AMZN to under $30.

Operating income, considered a key measure of Amazon's business performance, came in at $405 million, compared with $260 million in the year-ago period. Message.Title: Amazon Q4 Revs, EPS Light; But Margins Surprise Boosts Shares (Updated)
Message.Msg: Amazon Q4 Revs, EPS Light; But Margins Surprise Boosts Shares (Updated) CIO NETWORK | 1/29/2013 @ 4:03PM |1,893 views Amazon this afternoon reported what appear to be weaker-than-expected Q4 financial results, but the stock is trading sharply higher after hours, apparently due to better-than-expected margins in the quarter. Amazon posted revenues of $21.27 billion, up 22% from a year ago, below the Street consensus at $22.26 billion, and about in the middle of the company’s guidance range of $20.25 billion to $2.75 billion. Profits were 21 cents a share, shy of the Street at 29 cents. Net income was $97 million, down 45%. Operating income in the quarter was $405 million, up 56% from a year ago; that was actually better than the guidance range of -$490 million to positive $310 million. Gross margin was 24.1%, well ahead of the Street consensus at 21.9%, according to the stock news site StreetAccount. Non-GAAP operating margin also beat expectations, at 3.2%, ahead of the Street at 2.2%. “We’re now seeing the transition we’ve been expecting,” CEO Jeff Bezos said in a statement. “After 5 years, eBooks is a multi-billion dollar category for us and growing fast – up approximately 70% last year. In contrast, our physical book sales experienced the lowest December growth rate in our 17 years as a book seller, up just 5%. We’re excited and very grateful to our customers for their response to Kindle and our ever expanding ecosystem and selection.” For Q1, the company sees sales of $15 billion to $16.6 billion, below the Street at $16.86 billion, but up between 14% and 26% from a year ago. The company sees operating income for the quarter ranging from a loss of $285 million to positive $65 million. AMZN in late trading is up $15.31, or 5.9%, to $275.31. forbesDOTcom/sites/ericsavitz/2013/01/29/amazon-q4-misses-ests-revs-21-27b-profits-21-cents/

Message.Title: Some earnings insights
Message.Msg: First, they are up because their operating income upped the top end of the range. The earnings miss was due to equity in subsidiary and other expenses (unclear what other is or if they shifted things around). Very high tax rate over 50% probably due to realization of writedown on a deferred tax asset. That's the good news. The bad news: 1.Very bad revenue miss. This was probably due in part to bad Kindle Sales. Remember the Pacific Crest guy who brought forecasts down. This boosted profit in m opinion. When your gross margin is maybe -1% and operating margin on Kindle sales is like -11% and you come up maybe $60 million below expectations that boosts profit by $6.6 million and since Kindle sales were probably down as a percentage of total sales that might explain 20 basis points for so of gross margin. Keep in mind though, lower Kindle Sales mean lower e-book sales in future and less of the gross margin benefit in future years. Hence they top end of revnue guidance is below the consensus reflecting weaker Kindle and e-book sales and also a more generic weakness in revenues. Revenue problems was not driven by exchange rates. 2. If revenue growth slows down a lot of the benefits from negative operating working capital growth will slow down too in terms of FCF generation (from payables) 3. Diluted Share count up from 462 to 473. More dilution of investors. Also that means 11 million more shares at $280 per share (near recent prices) or $3.08 Billion more in valuation that must be justified. At $280m, we are talking $132.4 billion market cap at $280. 4. People are partying over gross margins, but guess what - not just a Kindle effect. As they get more service revenue gross margins go up but their fulfillment costs go up as well. Note that fulfillment went from 8.4% in Q42010 to 9.5% in Q42011 and now about 12.44% in Q4 2012. As gross margins rise, fulfillment costs rise too. 5. Firm's new trick is poor guidance. I model them getting just a bit above top of operating earnings range that is down from last year. 5. Weak sales might mean a sales tax hit. Guess what. That hit will occur eventually most of the rest of the country. Next 3 quarters mean tough comps after California tax hike. 6. No share repurchases lately. Amazon jumps in and buys when they think stock is undervalued. Last time was when prices were around 180 to 190 in fourth quarter last year and first quarter this year. No buying since suggesting Amazon thinks socik might be worth around $200 to $220 range. 7. Debt continues upward. Interest expense expanded again this quarter. Equity investments keep shedding value and probably will cause more income statement losses. Before equity investment numbers I have them with an EPS of around 8 cents and operating margins around 0.45%. With more equity losses we could see zero earnings or negative again. 8. Why is the firm borrowing $3 billion when they got tax benefits of $230million and are paying employees with stock to the tune of $450 billion to save on cash costs.

Message.Msg: your march puts will be about 20%-30% of the value they are now, your feb put will be worth about 10% of its value unless you see a $20+ drop early. the reason is, like it was mentioned by a previous post, almost all of the implied volatility will be gone after pre-market tomorrow. All of your calls will be worthless unless you see a $20+ rise early.these sharp moves are unlikely... after a little pump in the AM your more likely to see a slow drag down movement until a month before next earnings. AMZN missed its earnings, and that might not show up right away but it will show up. if your a profitable day trader then i suggest you stick with it. options is a totally different game. i also suggest if you disregard that advise you start reading... a lot. This is not uncommon for the closing price to change within a few seconds of close when the volume is so high all at once. Everyone was trying to position trades based on derivative positions right at close. In this case it was most likely call positions where traders took on a short position for protection, that later covered in AH, thus pushing the stock up significantly in AH. It will be interesting to see how this works itself tomorrow when real volume comes in.

Topic.Title: A 120 BILLION COMPANY AT 150 TIMES EARNINGS IS UNHEARD OF

Message.Msg: You are basically correct on the $ 120 billion market cap, but the P/E ratio of AMZN is currently over 3,000, not 150 as you suggest. Just think about it this way --- If there was a stock market 3,000 years ago and Amazon was traded on that exchange, then a person that invested $ 1.00 in Amazon would just now be getting his original $ 1.00 investment back. Not one single dime of profit, just his/her original investment. That investment would have been originally made approximately 1,500 years before Christ was even born! That my friend, is an analogy about a stock with a 3,000 P/E multiple that you should never forget. With that in mind, which direction do you really think the stock is most likely to head?
